facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 223 and 224 of 1960 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 223 and 224 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeals from order dated November 23, 1956 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Tax Revision Cases Nos. 17 and 18 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the order dated November 23, 1956, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court, Hyderabad, in Tax Revision Cases Nos. 17 and 18 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 14, 1960 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-

facts.text: In 1952-53, appellants dealt in gunnies and purchased them from two Mills in Vishakapatnam District.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1952-53, for which the assessment of sales tax was in question, the appellants dealt in gunnies, and purchased them from two Mills in Vishakapatnam District

facts.text: Appellants issued delivery orders to third parties with whom they had separate transactions.

anchor.surface_text: and in respect of which they issued delivery orders to third parties, with whom they had entered into separate transactions.

facts.text: Appellants entered into contracts with Mills agreeing to purchase gunnies at a certain rate for future delivery. Exhibit A-1 is specimen.

anchor.surface_text: They first entered into contracts with the Mills agreeing to purchase gunnies at a certain rate for future delivery. Exhibit A-1 is a specimen of such contracts.

facts.text: Appellants entered into agreements with Mills to deliver goods to third parties if requested, but Mills treated third parties as agents of appellants. Exhibits A-2 and A-2a specimens.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants also entered into agreements with the Mills, by which the Mills agreed to deliver the goods to third parties if requested by the appellants. The Mills, however, did not accept the third parties as contracting parties but only as agents of the appellants. Exhibits A-2 and A-2

facts.text: Before delivery date, appellants entered agreements with third parties, charged extra, handed kutcha delivery orders. Exhibits A-3 and A-4 specimens.

anchor.surface_text: Before the date of delivery, the appellants entered into agreements with third parties, by which they charged something extra from the third parties and handed over to them the delivery orders, which were known as kutcha delivery orders. Exhibits A-3 and A-4 are specimens of the agreement and the delivery orders respectively.

facts.text: Mills delivered goods against kutcha delivery orders along with invoice and bill, collected sales tax from third parties. Exs. A-6 and A-7 specimens.

anchor.surface_text: The Mills used to deliver the goods against the kutcha delivery orders along with an invoice and a bill, of which Exs. A-6 and A-7 are specimens respectively, and collected the sales tax from the third parties.

facts.text: Tax authorities treated transaction between appellants and third parties as fresh sale and levied sales tax again.

anchor.surface_text: The tax authorities, however, treated the transaction between the appellants and third parties as a fresh sale, and sought to levy sales tax on it again,

facts.text: Appellants contended no second sale, tax not demandable.

anchor.surface_text: which, the appellants, contended, was not demandable, as there was no second sale.

facts.text: Appellants failed before Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Guntur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants failed in their contentions before the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Guntur,

facts.text: Appeals to Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Guntur unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: and their appeals to the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Guntur and the Andhra Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, Guntur, were unsuccessful.

facts.text: Revision to High Court under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 as amended by Madras Act No. 6 of 1951 unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then went up in revision to the High Court under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 as amended by Madras Act No. 6 of 1951 , but were again unsuccessful.

facts.text: High Court granted certificates for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, granted certificates, on which these appeals have been filed.

facts.text: Appellants contended agreement and delivery of kutcha delivery order was assignment of right to obtain delivery, not sale.

anchor.surface_text: The contentions of the appellants are that the agreement and the delivery of the kutcha delivery order did not amount to a sale of goods, but was only an assignment of a right to obtain delivery of the gunnies,

facts.text: Alternatively, assignment of forward contract.

anchor.surface_text: or, in the alternative, that this was only an assignment of a forward contract.

facts.text: Appellants relied on Sales Tax Officer Pilibhit v. Budh Prakash and Poppatlal Shah v. State of Madras in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: They seem to have relied in the High Court upon the decisions of this Court reported in The Sales Tax Officer, Pilibhit v. Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash 1  and Poppatlal Shah v. The State of Madras  2

facts.text: Court held there were two separate sales: Mills to appellants, appellants to third parties; tax payable on both.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there being two separate transactions of sale, tax was payable at both the points, as has been correctly pointed out by the tax authorities and the High Court.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals fail, and are dismissed with costs.

issues.text: Whether the transaction between the appellants and third parties was a fresh sale subject to sales tax?

anchor.surface_text: The tax authorities, however, treated the transaction between the appellants and third parties as a fresh sale, and sought to levy sales tax on it again, which, the appellants, contended, was not demandable, as there was no second sale.

issues.text: Whether the agreement and the delivery of the kutcha delivery order amounted to a sale of goods or only an assignment of a right to obtain delivery of the gunnies which were not in existence or appropriated to the contract?

anchor.surface_text: The contentions of the appellants are that the agreement and the delivery of the kutcha delivery order did not amount to a sale of goods, but was only an assignment of a right to obtain delivery of the gunnies, which were not in existence at the time of the transaction with third parties, and were not appropriated to the contract, or,

issues.text: Whether the transaction was only an assignment of a forward contract?

anchor.surface_text: or, in the alternative, that this was only an assignment of a forward contract.

issues.text: Whether there were two separate transactions of sale with tax payable at both points?

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there being two separate transactions of sale, tax was payable at both the points, as has been correctly pointed out by the tax authorities and the High Court.

issues.text: Whether the mills recognised the third parties as contracting parties having privity with them?

anchor.surface_text: not recognising the third parties as contracting parties having privity with them

issues.text: Whether a delivery order is a document of title to goods enabling separate sales?

anchor.surface_text: s. 2 4 of the Sale of Goods Act

issues.text: Whether property in the goods passed from the mills to the assessee?

anchor.surface_text: property in the goods did not pass from the mills to the assessee

arguments.claim: Mills did not recognise third parties as contracting parties having privity, only as agents of appellants

anchor.surface_text: To begin with, the Mills had made clear in their agreements that they were not recognising the third parties as contracting parties having privity with them, and that delivery would be given against the kutcha delivery orders to the third parties as agents of the appellants.

arguments.claim: There was a sale from Mills to appellants on which sales tax was paid

anchor.surface_text: The Mills, therefore, recognised only the appellants as contracting parties, and there was thus a sale to the appellants from the Mills, on which ,sales tax was correctly demanded and was paid.

arguments.claim: Third parties purchased goods from appellants at extra price; fresh transaction of sale

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the third parties were concerned, they had purchased the goods by payment of an extra price, and the transaction must, in law and in fact, be considered a fresh transaction of sale between the appellants and the third parties.

arguments.claim: Delivery order is a document of title to goods under s. 2(4) Sale of Goods Act, allowing receipt and transfer

anchor.surface_text: A delivery order is a document of title to goods vide s. 2 4  of the Sale of Goods Act , and the possessor of such a document has the right not only to receive the goods but also to transfer it to another by endorsement or delivery.

arguments.claim: Two deliveries: Mills to appellants (via agents third parties), and appellants to third parties

anchor.surface_text: At the moment of delivery by the Mills to the third parties, there were, in effect, two deliveries, one by the Mills to the Appellants, represented, in so far as the Mills were concerned, by the appellants agents, the third parties, and the other, by the appellants to the third parties as buyers from the appellants.

arguments.claim: Two separate transactions of sale; tax payable at both points

anchor.surface_text: These two deliveries might synchronise in point of time, but were separate, in point of fact and in the eye of law. ... In our opinion, there being two separate transactions of sale, tax was payable at both the points,

arguments.claim: Tax authorities and High Court correctly held two sales taxable at both points

anchor.surface_text: as has been correctly pointed out by the tax authorities and the High Court.

arguments.claim: Andhra Pradesh High Court case in State of Andhra v. Kolla Sreeramamurty distinguished; different facts

anchor.surface_text: The appellants relied upon a decision of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in The State of Andhra v. Kolla Sreeramamurty  3 , but there, the facts were different, and the Division Bench itself in dealing with the case, distinguished the judgment under appeal, observing that there was no scope for the application of the principles laid down in the judgment under appeal, because in the cited case, the property in the goods did not pass from the mills to the assessee and there was no agreement of sale of goods to be obtained in future between the assessee and the third party.

holdings.text: there being two separate transactions of sale, tax was payable at both the points

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there being two separate transactions of sale, tax was payable at both the points, as has been correctly pointed out by the tax authorities and the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Two distinct sales identified: Mills to appellants and appellants to third parties via kutcha delivery orders functioning as documents of title, resulting in two synchronized but separate deliveries; tax authorities and High Court correctly applied law

holdings.text: the Mills had made clear in their agreements that they were not recognising the third parties as contracting parties having privity with them, and that delivery would be given against the kutcha delivery orders to the third parties as agents of the appellants

anchor.surface_text: To begin with, the Mills had made clear in their agreements that they were not recognising the third parties as contracting parties having privity with them, and that delivery would be given against the kutcha delivery orders to the third parties as agents of the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit terms in agreements (Exhibits A-2, A-2a) show Mills treated third parties only as agents of appellants, maintaining privity solely with appellants

holdings.text: there was thus a sale to the appellants from the Mills, on which sales tax was correctly demanded and was paid

anchor.surface_text: The Mills, therefore, recognised only the appellants as contracting parties, and there was thus a sale to the appellants from the Mills, on which ,sales tax was correctly demanded and was paid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mills' recognition of appellants as sole contracting parties and collection of tax from third parties as agents confirms first sale

holdings.text: the transaction must, in law and in fact, be considered a fresh transaction of sale between the appellants and the third parties

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the third parties were concerned, they had purchased the goods by payment of an extra price, and the transaction must, in law and in fact, be considered a fresh transaction of sale between the appellants and the third parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Third parties paid extra price to appellants for goods under separate agreements and kutcha delivery orders

holdings.text: A delivery order is a document of title to goods vide s. 2 4 of the Sale of Goods Act , and the possessor of such a document has the right not only to receive the goods but also to transfer it to another by endorsement or delivery

anchor.surface_text: A delivery order is a document of title to goods vide s. 2 4 of the Sale of Goods Act , and the possessor of such a document has the right not only to receive the goods but also to transfer it to another by endorsement or delivery.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definition under Sale of Goods Act s.2(4) enables possession to confer rights to receive and transfer goods, facilitating second sale

holdings.text: At the moment of delivery by the Mills to the third parties, there were, in effect, two deliveries, one by the Mills to the Appellants... and the other, by the appellants to the third parties as buyers from the appellants

anchor.surface_text: At the moment of delivery by the Mills to the third parties, there were, in effect, two deliveries, one by the Mills to the Appellants, represented, in so far as the Mills were concerned, by the appellants agents, the third parties, and the other, by the appellants to the third parties as buyers from the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agency role of third parties for Mills' delivery coincides with but does not merge appellants' delivery to third parties as buyers

holdings.text: this does not represent the true nature of the transactions, either in fact, or in law

anchor.surface_text: in our opinion, this does number represent the true nature of the transactions, either in fact, or in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants' contention of mere assignment rejected based on contractual privity, extra payment, and document of title enabling sale

holdings.text: there was no scope for the application of the principles laid down in the judgment under appeal, because in the cited case, the property in the goods did not pass from the mills to the assessee and there was no agreement of sale of goods to be obtained in future between the assessee and the third party

anchor.surface_text: The appellants relied upon a decision of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in The State of Andhra v. Kolla Sreeramamurty  3 , but there, the facts were different, and the Division Bench itself in dealing with the case, distinguished the judgment under appeal, observing that there was no scope for the application of the principles laid down in the judgment under appeal, because in the cited case, the property in the goods did not pass from the mills to the assessee and there was no agreement of sale of goods to be obtained in future between the assessee and the third party.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different facts in Andhra case: no property passage to assessee and no sale agreement with third party, distinguishing prior precedent

anchor.surface_text: The appellants relied upon a decision of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in The State of Andhra v. Kolla Sreeramamurty  3 , but there, the facts were different, and the Division Bench itself in dealing with the case, distinguished the judgment under appeal, observing that there was no scope for the application of the principles laid down in the judgment under appeal, because in the cited case, the property in the goods did not pass from the mills to the assessee and there was no agreement of sale of goods to be obtained in future between the assessee and the third party.
